definitions.definition: either of the two parts of the body between the top of each arm and the neck
definitions.sensetop: over somebody's shoulderon somebody's shoulderaround somebody's shoulder
definitions.labels: (informal)(formal)(British English)(British English)(disapproving)(both informal, often disapproving)(informal, disapproving)

examples.text: your **left/right shoulder**
a tall man with broad shoulders
He slung the bag over his shoulder.
He **looked** back **over his shoulder**.
He carried the child on his shoulders.
I put a hand on her shoulder to stop her.
She tapped him on the shoulder.
He put an arm around her shoulders and pulled her close.
She **shrugged her shoulders** *(= showing that she didn't know or care)*.
an **off-the-shoulder** dress *(= that does not cover the shoulders)*
a **shoulder injury**
I have to have **shoulder surgery**.
He hunched his shoulders against the cold wind.
Her shoulders lifted in a vague shrug.
His broad shoulders heaved with sobs.
His frozen shoulder has stopped him from playing tennis.
In an aggressive situation, we stand tall and square our shoulders.
Inhale, drop your shoulders and raise your chest.
Keep the feet shoulder width apart.
My shoulders dropped with relief.
Roll your shoulders forward and take a deep breath.
She was crouched with her head forward and her shoulders bent.
The child sat on her father's shoulders to watch the parade go by.

definitions.definition: having the type of shoulders mentioned

examples.text: broad-shouldered

definitions.definition: the part of a piece of clothing that covers the shoulder

examples.text: a jacket with padded shoulders
There was snow on the shoulders of his heavy black coat.

definitions.definition: meat from the top part of one of the front legs of an animal that has four legs
a part of something, such as a bottle or mountain, that is like a shoulder in shape

examples.text: The village lay just around the shoulder of the hill.

definitions.definition: an area of ground at the side of a road where vehicles can stop in an emergency

examples.text: No shoulder for next 5 miles *(= on a notice)*.

definitions.definition: to be much better than other people or things

examples.text: His performance stood head and shoulders above the rest.

definitions.definition: to be anxious and have the feeling that somebody is going to do something unpleasant or harmful to you
to treat somebody in a way that is not friendly
to be sensitive about something that happened in the past and become easily offended if it is mentioned because you think that you were treated unfairly

examples.text: He has a real chip on his shoulder about not being chosen for the team.

definitions.definition: used to describe a young person who acts in a more sensible way than you would expect for a person of their age
if blame, guilt, etc. is on somebody’s shoulders, they must take responsibility for it

examples.text: Stop trying to put the blame on somebody else’s shoulders.

definitions.definition: to start working very hard at a particular task

examples.text: Everyone is going to have to put their shoulder to the wheel.

definitions.definition: to meet and spend time with a famous person, socially or as part of your job

examples.text: He’s rubbing shoulders with stars all the time.
She had been rubbing elbows with celebrities.

definitions.definition: used to describe a person who listens to your problems and gives you sympathy

examples.text: He was a fatherly shoulder to cry on when things went wrong.
The large crowd stood shoulder to shoulder in the stands.
The route of the procession was lined with police officers standing shoulder to shoulder.

definitions.definition: as one group that has the same aims, opinions, etc.
if you say something straight from the shoulder, you are being very honest and direct, even if what you are saying is critical

wordOrigin: Old English sculdor, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch schouder and German Schulter.
